MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Importation of Tropical Hardwoods.

Qst.Quest: if he proposes to establish a ban on the import of tropical hardwoods into Ireland; if he will encourage the EC to operate a similar ban at EC level in order to reduce the economic pressure on the threatened tropical rain-forests; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Industry and Commerce (Mr. O'Malley) Desmond J. O'Malley
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Industry and Commerce (Mr. O'Malley)
Speaker.P: It is not proposed to establish a ban on the import of tropical hardwoods into Ireland. Ireland's obligations under the International Tropical Timber Agreement, 1983, the terms of which were approved by the House on 28 June 1984, preclude active discouragement of imports of tropical timber. Such a step would also run counter to the provisions of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade.

I fully agree, however, that the problem of tropical forest destruction, encompassing as it does environmental, economic, trade and political issues, requires urgent action based on a worldwide co-ordinated strategy for tropical forest resources. Ireland's participation in such action can be best achieved within the framework of the EC where it is agreed that any action, to be effective, would have to be on the basis of a broad consensus between consumers and producers.
The EC General Affairs Council of 29 May 1990 endorsed the following principles and activities:

Responsibility for tropical forests lies with the countries concerned. Donors should concentrate on supporting action taken by the developing countries themselves and, where necessary, help them to develop forest conservation strategies and to strengthen their institutional capacity in this sector.

MainHeading.P: The Tropical Forestry Action Plan (TFAP)* should be the basic framework for co-ordinated funding and action in the support of forest activities.The council urges the Community and the member states to support current efforts to implement the principles of the TFAP, considers these efforts need to be reinforced and made more effective, and welcomes the review of the TFAP now under way. The council will examine the results of that review at a forthcoming meeting together with ways of making the TFAP more effective.

*The TFAP is an FAO sponsored mechanism, involving the UN and the World Bank, designed to co-ordinate the efforts of a variety of international entities — governmental and non-governmental, co-operating towards the conservation and rational use of tropical forest resources.

Countries actively supporting the conservation of their remaining natural forests through legal, fiscal and institutional measures, and the revision of land use policies should merit special attention. Action to correct policies which encourage forest destruction should also be fostered and supported.

Member states and the Commission should ensure that all their activities which directly or indirectly affect forests are coherent and co-ordinated among themselves and with other donors and recipients and that they have effective units with the necessary forestry expertise.

The future geographical allocation of forestry aid should be co-ordinated using the mechanism of the TFAP. Priority must continue to be given to the poorest countries and those without the resources to help themselves. However, regions where the threat to forests is particularly serious and which may not previously have been a priority for donors should receive particular attention in the allocation of additional resources.

The type of support will vary from country to country in accordance with their particular needs. Particular emphasis must be given, in line with the priorities of the TFAP, to the integration of forestry actions with agriculture; restoration of fuelwood supplies; the establishment of reserves based on the environmental and biodiversity functions of forests; the sustained management of natural forests; and so strengthening and supporting institutions, with a view to increasing local capacity for sustainable management.There is a need for donors to co-ordinate their actions as regards countries and sectors.

Particular importance has to be attached to the social dimension of forestry.The traditions and experience of indigenous forest dwellers should be respected and drawn upon while at the same time the needs and problems of new settlers and those living on the periphery of the forest should be addressed. Active steps should be taken to involve local populations in planning and implementation of projects.
Special emphasis must be given to the involvement of international and national NGOs in the TFAP process, particularly at local level.

Particular consideration should be given to the role of the International Timber Trade Organisation (ITTO) in promoting sustainable management, notably in establishing guidelines for best practice in this sector. The ITTO should be encouraged to carry out its actions in a manner consistent with the TFAP framework.

The Council notes the recent adoption, at the 8th session of the ITTO, of guidelines for the rational management of natural tropical forests and of an action plan and work programme on forest industry, and particularly the objective that total exports of tropical timber products should come from sustainedly managed resources by the year 2000.

Forestry research is of fundamental importance. Particular emphasis should be placed on improving sustainable productivity of forests; identifying non-timber resources of the forest and key areas of biodiversity, and evaluating the environmental services provided by trees and forests. Reinforcement of the research capacities of the developing countries themselves should be a priority.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Commission on Social Welfare Report.

Qst.Quest: if he accepts the recommendation in the Commission on Social Welfare report that those aged 16 to 18 years who need and independent income should be catered for by the reformed supplementary welfare allowance scheme; and the steps he is taking to implement this proposal.

if he accepts the recommendation in the Commission on Social Welfare report that clear guidelines should be set out with regard to the discretionary features of a reformed supplementary welfare system, such as exceptional needs payments, and that they should be subject to review every two years; and the steps he is taking to implement this proposal.

if he accepts the recommendation in the Commission on Social Welfare report that the supplementary welfare allowance appeals should be included in the general appeals system; and the steps he is taking to implement this proposal.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Dr. Woods) Michael J. Woods
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 132, 153 and 161 together.

I believe that all income maintenance services should be delivered in a co-ordinated and cost-effective manner and that clients should, as far as practicable, have one point of contact in claiming their entitlements. This means that, in the long term, I would envisage the transfer of supplementary welfare allowance and disabled person's maintenance allowance from health boards to the Department of Social Welfare.

There are major issues to be addressed in relation to any such transfer. These include making arrangements in relation to staffing, computerisation, and the setting up of suitable management structures.It will also be necessary to ensure that certain features of the schemes, such as a localised service and links to health and welfare services, are not adversely affected in any transfer.

These aspects need to be worked out in detail by my Department, in consultation with the Department of Health and the health boards. When this process is completed, I will be in a position to present more definite proposals on a possible transfer.
The arrangements for appeals under the supplementary welfare allowance scheme will be considered in the context of the future arrangement for administration of the scheme.
The operation of the scheme is kept under review on an ongoing basis and revised guidelines or circular letters are issued in response to emerging needs.

The guidelines on the operation of the scheme are kept under review and general directions are issued to health boards from time to time as appropriate. Following a comprehensive review of the provisions for rent and mortgage supplementation revised guidelines on this aspect of the scheme have been issued. The area of exceptional needs payments is under review and revised guidelines, which are also aimed at achieving greater uniformity of treatment, are being prepared.

MainHeading.P: The provision of assistance towards the cost of school clothing has been one of the most important elements of exceptional needs payments. In this connection the new back-to-school clothing scheme which I am introducing this year will benefit over 170,000 children whose parents are dependent on social welfare and health board payments. There will be two rates of allowance — £40 for each secondary school child and £25 for each primary school child. These particular payments will replace the discretionary aspect of the arrangements in operation heretofore under the exceptional needs provisions of the supplementary welfare allowances scheme as applied in the case of school uniforms and will also bring about greater uniformity of treatment.

In relation to persons aged 16 to 18 years the supplementary welfare allowances scheme is sufficiently flexible to cater for the needs of vulnerable 16-18 year olds who are without financial support and need an independent income in circumstances such as those outlined in the commission's report. I have no plans at present to change the scheme's provisions in this regard.

Qst.Quest: if he accepts the recommendation in the Commission on Social Welfare report that the free electricity allowance and the free fuel allowance should be extended to include all long-term recipients; and the steps he is taking to implement this proposal.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Dr. Woods) Michael J. Woods
Speaker.P: The schemes in question apply to persons who are elderly or permanently incapacitated, are receiving certain social security-type payments and are either living alone or only with a dependent spouse or other excepted persons.

MainHeading.P: In 1987 I extended the national fuel scheme to the long term unemployed. This year, I am further extending entitlement under the free schemes. Inter alia, pensioners over 80 years are to be allowed to retain their free electricity entitlement when people come to live with them. In addition, the anomaly whereby an invalidity pensioner with free scheme entitlement loses this entitlement on transferring to retirement pension at age 65 is being removed.
Further extentions of these schemes to include additional categories of beneficiaries would have cost implications and is a matter for consideration in a budgetary context.

Qst.Quest: if he accepts the recommendation in the Commission on Social Welfare report that duration of unemployment benefits should be extended as an immediate priority for the unemployed in the middle and older age groups; and the steps he is taking to implement this proposal.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Dr. Woods) Michael J. Woods
Speaker.P: I am not satisfied at present that extending the duration of unemployment benefit would in the longer term benefit those who have been unemployed for some time. In recent years, the Government's priority has been to improve the level of payment for those who are long term unemployed, particularly those with families. It is for this reason that special increases have been given to this group.

The question of extending the duration of unemployment benefit beyond 15 months would have to be considered in a context of available resources and the need to target those resources at the long term unemployed.

Qst.Quest: if he accepts the recommendation in the Commission on Social Welfare report that specific provision should be introduced for those affected by the former earnings limit with intermittent insurance contributions who fail to qualify for a retirement or old age contributory pension, or those with mixed insurance contributions who fail to qualify for a full occupational pension or qualify for an occupational pension the rate of which is lower than that of an old age contributory pension; and the steps he is taking to implement this proposal.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Dr. Woods) Michael J. Woods
Speaker.P: I made arrangements under the Social Welfare Act, 1988, for the payment of pro rata pensions to a specific group of insured persons with intermittent social insurance records. These persons had been excluded from compulsory social insurance cover for periods prior to 1974 by reason of the upper earnings limit which then applied. They were brought back into compulsory insurance in 1974, when that limit was abolished but subsequently failed to qualify for contributory pension because of the gaps in their insurance records prior to 1974.

This arrangement does not cover the situation of persons with mixed insurance records partly at the full rate and partly at a modified rate who do not qualify for pension because of an insufficient contributions record at the full rate. The National Pensions Board is considering this issue and will be submitting proposals on the matter in its final report which is expected later this year. Priority will be given to consideration of the board's recommendation on this matter with a view to the introduction of appropriate measures at the earliest possible date.

Qst.Quest: if he accepts the recommendation in the Commission on Social Welfare report that all public servants and office holders should be liable for the standard rate of PRSI and be entitled to benefits as appropriate; and the steps he is taking to implement this proposal.

if he accepts the recommendation in the Commission on Social Welfare report that social insurance should be extended to all ministers of religion and members of religious communities who would be entitled to benefits as appropriate; and the steps he is taking to implement this proposal.

if he accepts the recommendation in the Commission on Social Welfare report that PRSI should be extended to all employee income without a ceiling; and the steps he is taking to implement this proposal.

if he accepts the recommendation in the Commission on Social Welfare Report that, if levies for other purposes are to be retained, they should be integrated with the income tax systems and not be collected as part of PRSI; and the steps he is taking to implement this proposal.

if he accepts the recommendation in the Commission on Social Welfare report that some other mechanism should be found for giving tax relief to certain employees rather than through PRSI tax allowances; and the steps he is taking to implement this proposal.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Dr. Woods) Michael J. Woods
Speaker.P: It is proposed to take Questions Nos. 136, 137, 139, 140 and 141 together.

MainHeading.P: Since the publication of the Report of the Commission on Social Welfare I have made a number of changes to the PRSI contributions system, in line with the view of the commission that the base for contributions should be as wide as possible. Social insurance has been extended to the self-employed, including farmers, and to ministers of religion and members of religious orders. As announced in last year's budget, the Government have decided in principle to extend full social insurance cover to public sector workers currently on the modified rate of contribution. My colleague the Minister for Finance and myself have commenced discussions on this matter with the interests concerned. The social insurance base has been further widened by the raising of the income ceiling for contributions. When the commission furnished its report the ceiling was £14,700 for both employer and employee contributions; it is now £17,300 for employees and the self-employed and £18,600 for employers. Any further changes to the ceiling, including its possible elimination, would have to be considered in a budgetary context having particular regard to the interaction between the tax and PRSI systems and their joint impact on take-home pay across the whole range of income levels.

The question of integrating the levies into the income tax system is a matter for the Minister for Finance. It is estimated that receipts from the health contribution and the employment and training levy in 1990 will amount to over £250 million. The implementation of the proposal would have to be considered by the Minister for Finance having regard to its impact on the levels of taxation for individual taxpayers.

The question of the PRSI tax allowance would also have to be considered in this context. However, since the commission reported, the Government have also taken steps to reduce the PRSI burden on the low paid. This year we introduced a new arrangement whereby employees on low earnings, £60 per week or less, do not have to pay PRSI contributions, but continue to qualify for benefits. It is estimated that this measure will improve the take-home pay of over 50,000 workers. Low paid workers will also benefit from the increases in tax exemption limits in the past two budgets, and the introduction of the new exemption limits for people with children. An interdepartmental committee is currently examining the effects of tax and PRSI contributions on the incomes of the low paid, and further developments will be considered in the light of the committee's recommendations.

Qst.Quest: if he accepts the recommendation in the Commission on Social Welfare report that the components of the means test should be widely publicised; and the steps he is taking to implement this proposal.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Dr. Woods) Michael J. Woods
Speaker.P: The Commission on Social Welfare recommended that the components of the means test should be widely publicised so as to ensure that lack of knowledge in relation to the means assessment provisions does not adversely affect the level of take-up of social welfare payments.

I am very conscious of the need to ensure that detailed information in relation to all aspects of social welfare entitlements is widely and easily available to claimants and a considerable amount of progress has been made in this area since the publication of the commission's report.

The information leaflets on each of the schemes administered by my Department have been revised. These leaflets contain detailed information in relation to the particular scheme including comprehensive information on the means assessment provisions. The most recently revised leaflets including information on means tests include those for old age pensioners, widows, deserted wives and other lone parents. A new leaflet on unemployment assistance also gives detailed information on the means test.

In addition to the information leaflets on individual schemes, a comprehensive Guide to Social Welfare Services has also been made available from my Department.An updated version of this guide is being prepared at present and all aspects of the guide, including information in relation to the assessment of means, are being reviewed in this context.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Commission on Social Welfare Report.

Qst.Quest: if he accepts the recommendation in the Commission on Social Welfare report that the family income supplement should in the long term be phased as child benefit and marginal tax rates evolve in order to render family income supplement unnecessary; and the steps he is taking to implement this proposal.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Dr. Woods) Michael J. Woods
Speaker.P: Family income supplement (FIS) when introduced in 1984 was designed to increase the take home pay of those on low earnings from work relative to weekly social welfare rates.

The Commission on Social Welfare recommended that for the moment FIS should be retained and improved, modifying the conditions of entitlement in order to increase the rates of payments and the take-up of the scheme. Substantial improvements have been made in the FIS scheme since publication of the commission's report. In the last year I have improved the scheme in several ways, namely; income limits have been increased from between £4 and £38 depending on family size; maximum payments have been increased by between £2 per week and £21 per week depending on family size; extra payments for families with more than five children; the rate of supplement has been increased from 50 per cent to 60 per cent of the difference between family income and relevant income limit; and the number of hours required to work in order to qualify for FIS has been reduced from 24 to 20; hours worked by both spouse can be added to reach this total. As a result of these improvements there has been an almost 20 per cent increase in the uptake of FIS in the past year.

In this year's budget an extra £1 million has been allocated for FIS improvements.This will be used to increase payments and the new rates will be announced shortly. I feel that the FIS scheme provides an essential boost to low income families and there are no plans at present to phase out the scheme.

Qst.Quest: if he accepts the recommendations in the Commission on Social Welfare report that the additional income needs of families who are long-term dependent on social welfare benefit should be met by additional payments equivalent to the weekly value of child dependant allowances, paid on a quarterly basis; and the steps he is taking to implement this proposal.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Dr. Woods) Michael J. Woods
Speaker.P: This year I am introducing a new back to school clothing allowance to help families on social welfare payments with the costs of school clothing for their children at the start of the coming school year. This allowance will be of major benefit to the families concerned and recognises the difficulties that many families on social welfare experience in meeting these costs.

I have taken the opportunity to combine the clothing and footwear assistance which I am providing in a new simplified clothing and footwear scheme at two rates — £40 for each secondary school child and £25 for each primary school child. Over 170,000 children of people dependent on health board and social welfare payments, including unemployment assistance, will benefit at a cost of £5.3 million. This figure includes the extra £3 million which I am now providing for clothing and the amount hitherto provided for children's footwear under the footwear scheme and for school uniforms.

Christmas is another expensive time for families, and for a number of years now it has been the practice to pay a Christmas bonus to all long-term social welfare recipients. Last year's bonus was 70 per cent of the weekly payment.

As well as providing these additional payments on occasions when they are most needed, the Government have been pursuing a policy of generally improving the position of long-term social welfare recipients with children. This year's improvements include an increase in the minimum child dependant payment from £10 to £11, the payment of child dependant increases until age 20 to recipients of long-term payments where the child continues in full-time education, and a 5 per cent increase in the rate of child benefit.
I believe that these measures represent an effective and well targeted approach to meeting the income needs of families who are long-term dependant on social welfare.

Qst.Quest: if he accepts the recommendation in the Commission on Social Welfare report that the orphan's pension level should correspond to that of the foster care allowance; and the steps he is taking to implement this proposal.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Dr. Woods) Michael J. Woods
Speaker.P: There are three orphan's pension schemes administered by my Department — the orphan's contributory allowance, the orphan's non-contributory pension and the orphan's pension payable under the occupational injuries scheme. The purpose of these schemes is to provide an income maintenance payment in respect of children where both parents are dead or where one parent is dead and the other parent has abandoned or failed to support the children. The orphan's pension is normally paid to the guardian with whom the child lives or who is looking after the child's finances. In the majority of cases orphans are cared for by relatives, e.g. grandparents, aunts, uncles.

In examining the social welfare payments structure the Commission on Social Welfare recommended that the level of payment for child dependants should be £10 per week, in 1985 terms — approximately £12 per week in current terms. The orphan's pension payments range from £30 to £36.90 a week, July 1990 rates.

The National Pensions Board are currently preparing their final report on the future development of a national pension system and are examining in that context the pension arrangements for survivors, including orphans. The future development of the orphan's pension schemes will be examined in the light of that report, which is expected to be completed later this year.

Qst.Quest: if he accepts the recommendation in the Commission on Social Welfare report that present signing-on arrangements should be modified in order to provide claimants with greater choice as to the method of payment; and the steps he is taking to implement this proposal.

if he accepts the recommendation in the Commission on Social Welfare report that there should be a common register of all unemployed persons kept by the National Manpower Service and his Department; and the steps he is taking to implement this proposal.

if he accepts the recommendation in the Commission on Social Welfare report that sufficient resources should be devoted to computer development, in an accelerated programme, to enable his Department to introduce an integrated system covering information, payments and records for all schemes; and the steps he is taking to implement this proposal.

if he accepts the recommendation in the Commission on Social Welfare report that claimants should be given a choice of having their payments made by means of electronic fund transfer to a named account at banks, post offices or other financial institutions; and the steps he is taking to implement this proposal.

if he accepts the recommendation in the Commission on Social Welfare report that the administration of the social welfare system should be localised as far as possible with local offices being in a position to have access to information held at headquarters; and the steps he is taking to implement this proposal.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Dr. Woods) Michael J. Woods
Speaker.P: It is proposed to take Questions Nos. 145, 148, 155, 157 and 158 together.

MainHeading.P: I am fully committed to the provision of a modern, accessible and integrated service to social welfare clients at local level and considerable progress has been achieved in this regard in recent years. The appropriate computer and telecommunications infrastructure has been designed and is already substantially in place. Many of the Department's local offices outside Dublin are now fully linked to the system and all offices will be connected to the network within two years.

Plans for a new management structure, increasing the role of the local offices, have also been developed and will be brought into effect shortly when consultation are completed. Various interim improvements in the payment systems have also been made in the last few years and discussions are taking place on options to provide a fully comprehensive set of modern arrangements tailored to the needs of social welfare recipients. These new arrangements will involve new signing arrangements for many of the unemployed.

Computer facilities are used extensively in the processing and payment of all types of social welfare benefits, allowances and pensions. With the exception of claims to unemployment benefit and assistance at the smaller offices outside Dublin, every claim made is now registered promptly and managed throughout its life cycle on the computers giving a nationwide consistency in treatment and a speedier and more accessible service at local level.

Computer facilities are being progressively deployed at local level on a phased basis. Thirty four information centres in local offices throughout the country use the computer links to directly access the Department's computer database for the purposes of answering clients' queries about their claims or entitlements. Many of the points of contact at local level can now provide clients with detailed, up to the minute information in relation to their claims.

In an important and innovative development, these inquiry facilities have also been extended to certain other agencies which deal with social welfare clients e.g. FÁS, certain health boards and a housing authority adding greatly to the improved service social welfare clients can expect as a new norm. Where facilities permit, data on unemployment payments is passed weekly by my Department to FÁS. These arrangements will be expanded as more offices are computerised. In addition, under the Jobsearch programme, certain of the long term unemployed are referred to FÁS for interview and assessment with a view to finding suitable training or employment.

In a development which I launched at Cork in 1987, intermediate medical certificates in respect of disability benefit claims are entered directly to the computer system at 17 locations across the country. This was work which previously was confined to headquarters with some inevitable resultant delays and queries.

By the end of the year, this important service will be available at a total of 27 offices and the remaining offices will come on stream next year. This project demonstrates the manner in which existing computer systems will be enhanced extensively to provide cohesive support to a new range of local services.

Very considerable resources have been made available in recent years to achieve the current progress and to generate the potential for further developments of the type I have outlined. Now that the physical infrastructure is on course for completion within a short time frame, I will be ensuring that the computer applications which run on the systems are enhanced and made available at a quickening pace. With that objective in mind, I recently augmented the management in the computer development area as a first step in the next phase of progress.

Qst.Quest: if he accepts the recommendation in the Commission on Social Welfare report that the unemployed should be allowed to engage in short term education courses which enhance their personal development and their prospects for employment, without endangering their benefit/assistance payments; and the steps he is taking to implement this proposal.

if he accepts the recommendation in the Commission on Social Welfare report that a working party should be established to consider the administrative issues involved in allowing the unemployed to engage in paid work on a part-time basis; and the steps he is taking to implement this proposal.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Dr. Woods) Michael J. Woods
Speaker.P: It is proposed to take Questions Nos. 146 and 147 together.

I am conscious of the fact that education and training play a vital role in helping unemployed persons to improve their prospects of securing employment particularly in the case of those who left the school system early. Social welfare legislation already allows persons, other than full-time day students, to engage in educational courses without affecting their entitlements and I have taken measures to ensure that deciding officers at employment exchanges are fully aware of the scope of these provisions.
In addition I have taken a number of special initiatives in recent years to facilitate unemployed people wishing to undertake full-time courses of education.

Under regulations which I introduced last year, certain unemployment assistance applicants may engage in a full-time course of education and at the same time satisfy the statutory condition of being available for work. The regulations cover participation by a person aged 21 years or over in a course of education at second level at a recognised centre.

The education opportunities scheme, which is now the vocational training opportunities scheme enables certain unemployed persons to follow a full-time education and training course in vocational education colleges at 12 locations throughout the country. To be eligible to participate in one of these courses a person has to have been receiving unemployment benefit or unemployment assistance for at least 15 months and must be over 21 years of age.

MainHeading.P: I am currently drawing up arrangements to facilitate the participation of long-term unemployed persons in third level education course and community enterprise type projects by way of pilot scheme. In relation to part-time working there is a considerable amount of flexibility in relation to part-time working within the existing legislation. For instance, a claimant may work part-time for up to three full days in any week and be eligible for unemployment payments for the remaining days of that week.

In addition, the part-time job incentive scheme, which I launched on a nation-wide basis in 1988, provides considerable scope to long-term unemployed persons who get the opportunity to take up a part-time job. Under this scheme eligible persons may work up to 24 hours a week in insurable employment while receiving a flat rate allowance instead of their unemployment payments. The allowances are £30 for a single person and £50 for a person with a dependent spouse. These rates will be increased in line with the general increase in payments in July. There are about 250 people participating in the scheme at present.

Qst.Quest: if he accepts the recommendation in the Commission on Social Welfare report that, in relation to one parent families, the condition whereby in order to qualify for a deserted wife's benefit/allowance, a women must prove that her husband left of his own volition, should be discontinued; and the steps he is taking to implement this proposal.

if he accepts the recommendation in the Commission on Social Welfare report that, in relation to one parent families, the condition whereby in order to qualify a deserted wife's benefit/allowance, a women must prove that her husband left of his own volition, should be discontinued; and the steps he is taking to implement this proposal.

if he accepts the recommendation in the Commission of Social Welfare report that, in relation to one parent families, the use of non-adversarial channels to obtain maintenance by agreement should be construed as reasonable efforts to secure maintenance in a flexible way; and the steps he is taking to implement this proposal.

if he accepts the recommendation in the Commission on Social Welfare report that in relation to one parent families, where the maintenance payment is irregular or uncertain, the State should have power to award a deserted wife's benefit/allowance and should pursue outstanding maintenance claims; and the steps he is taking to implement this proposal.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Dr. Woods) Michael J. Woods
Speaker.P: It is proposed to take Questions Nos. 149, 150 and 151 together.

The new lone parent's allowance scheme, which I am introducing in October 1990, will, in addition to streamlining the current arrangements for lone parents, provide a means-tested payment for all lone parents bringing up children.

The new scheme will incorporate the existing schemes for unmarried mothers, widowers and deserted husbands. In addition, recipients of widow's (noncontributory) pension, deserted wife's allowance and prisoner's wife's allowance who have dependent children will be brought within the scope of the scheme. The new scheme formally recognises that all parents bringing up children on their own face similar problems, regardless of the circumstances giving rise to their situation. Accordingly, the scope of the lone parent's allowance scheme is being extended to cover all separated persons, who will in future be able to qualify without having to prove that they have been deserted by their spouse.

I am also introducing new measures to assist lone parent families who are having difficulties obtaining maintenance. I have provided in legislation an obligation on men and women to maintain their dependent spouses and children. Where a liable relative fails or neglects to maintain his dependants and payments have been awarded under the deserted spouses', lone parent's or the supplementary welfare allowance schemes, the liable relative will be required to contribute towards the cost of such payments. These new provisions will be brought into force by way of commencement order at the same time as the new lone parent's allowance.

MainHeading.P: Implementation of these provisions will mean that the Department of Social Welfare and the health boards, in the case of supplementary welfare allowance, will in effect be assuming responsibility in such cases for requiring liable relatives to meet their maintenance obligations to their dependants. This outcome will be very much in line with the recommendations of the Commission on Social Welfare in this regard.

Qst.Quest: if he accepts the recommendation in the Commission on Social Welfare report that his Department should make arrangements for interim means-testing and payment at the centre where a person applies for payments, in order that the supplementary welfare allowance scheme can revert to its intended function as a residual income maintenance scheme catering for situations of special need; and the steps he is taking to implement this proposal.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Dr. Woods) Michael J. Woods
Speaker.P: It is the policy of my Department to ensure that new claims are determined as quickly as possible so that payment can be made to those who are entitled to it with a minimum of delay. To this end a number of measures have been taken in the last few years which are designed to speed up the processing of claims. For instance, certain straightforward types of unemployment assistance applications are no longer referred to a social welfare officer for investigation; instead the means are assessed on the basis of the facts presented and on information already available to the Department.

MainHeading.P: In other cases which are referred for investigation, the social welfare officer now generally interviews the claimants at an Office of the Department in the first instance and, as a result, the means in many cases can be assessed without the need for a visit to the claimant's home. It is planned to extend these types of arrangements in the coming years, not only as regards unemployment payments, but also to embrace other categories of social welfare claimants. In this way, the number of substitute payments made under the supplementary welfare scheme will be substantially reduced. The objective is to have a one-stop local centre where people can call and transact their business with my Department, no matter what scheme is involved.

Qst.Quest: if he accepts the recommendation in the Commission on Social Welfare report that the administration of treatment benefits should be transferred to the Department of Health; and the steps he is taking to implement this proposal.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Dr. Woods) Michael J. Woods
Speaker.P: The social insurance treatment benefits scheme, which includes dental and optical benefits, is a scheme specifically for persons insured under the social insurance system and their dependent spouses. Entitlement is determined by reference to reckonable PRSI contributions.I consider that the most effective way of administering the scheme is under the Department of Social Welfare as at present.

Qst.Quest: if he accepts the recommendation in the Commission on Social Welfare report that the grounds for refusal of payment should be more fully explained to applicants; and the steps he is taking to implement this proposal.

if he accepts the recommendation in the Commission on Social Welfare report that information on the reason for the rejection of an appeal should be given to the appellant; and the steps he is taking to implement this proposal.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Dr. Woods) Michael J. Woods
Speaker.P: It is proposed to take Questions Nos. 156 and 160 together.

MainHeading.P: The whole question of the provision of information to social welfare claimants is under examination in my Department. I want to ensure that all decisions are explained fully and coherently to the people concerned. Progress has been made in recent years in this area, particularly in relation to cases involving means assessments, and in relation to pensions.
Further progress will be made in the context of improvements in systems of delivery of social welfare schemes and in particular the greater automation of claim processing.
It will be a specific feature of the procedures for the new social welfare appeals office that appeal officers will give full details of the reasons for disallowance of an appeal in any case.

Qst.Quest: if he accepts the recommendation in the Commission on Social Welfare report that further resources should be devoted to staff development and all training personnel should be integrated into a reorganised staff training unit; and the steps he is taking to implement this proposal.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Dr. Woods) Michael J. Woods
Speaker.P: Training resources within my Department are continually developing to provide the necessary support for my Department's staff.

Training policy and the management of training is already integrated in my Department's staff Development Unit. However, Government policy on decentralisation of the Civil Service, and my own policy of greater localisation of social welfare services calls for a devolved approach to the delivery of training which is more efficient and cost effective than central delivery. The centrally based staff development unit will, in this context, continue to support and advise the locally based staff engaged on training duties. Its role and function will continue to be reviewed taking account of changing requirements in relation to the delivery of my Department's services.

Qst.Quest: if he accepts the recommendation in the Commission on Social Welfare report that his Department should be more actively involved in undertaking research on the social welfare system and should be provided with the necessary resources and autonomy to do so; and the steps he is taking to implement this proposal.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Dr. Woods) Michael J. Woods
Speaker.P: My Department have commissioned extensive research into the social welfare system since the publication of the Commission on Social Welfare Report in 1986.

As part of the second EC Poverty Programme I arranged for a report on poverty to be prepared by the ESRI. This report was based on a major survey carried out by the institute and was funded jointly by the institute, the Combat Poverty Agency and the EC. The report was published in October 1989 and a number of other reports have been made based on the survey's findings.

Arising from that report the Combat Poverty Agency are funding a number of further research projects based on the ESRI survey covering child poverty, take-up of social welfare benefits and income sharing arrangements in households.The Combat Poverty Agency are also funding two research projects on supplementary welfare allowance and has recently received approval from my Department to undertake a quantitative study of the living standards of families on welfare.

Apart from commissioned research my Department also have an ongoing programme of research and analysis of different aspects of the social welfare system and this has made a major input into the developments and improvements in the system in recent years.

Qst.Quest: the number of persons who have had unemployment benefit/ assistance altered due to the new co-habiting regulations under the terms of the Social Welfare (No. 2) Act, 1989; the number of such persons who have appealed unfavourable decisions made against them under these regulations; and the number of those appeals which were successful.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Dr. Woods) Michael J. Woods
Speaker.P: The information sought by the Deputy is not available. Statistics are not maintained on the various legislative bases of decisions given by deciding officers and appeals officers under the Social Welfare Acts.

Qst.Quest: when a person (details supplied) in Waterford will be paid a living alone allowance and arrears due; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Dr. Woods) Michael J. Woods
Speaker.P: The person concerned has been awarded living alone allowance from 5 January 1990.
A payable order book for £3.90 per week issued to his local post office on 13 June 1990. The book is payable from 25 May 1990.
Arrears of £78.00 for the period 5 January 1990 to 18 May 1990 will issue within 14 days.

Qst.hpid: Mr. G. Reynolds Mr. G. Reynolds
Qst.Quest: when a decision will be made on the unemployment assistance appeal of a person (details supplied) in County Leitrim.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Dr. Woods) Michael J. Woods
Speaker.P: The unemployment assistance claim of the person concerned was disallowed on 10 April 1990 on the grounds that the did not satisfy he statutory condition of being available for work.
He has appealed against the disallowance and has been granted an oral hearing fixed for Friday, 22 June at which it will be open to him to attend and give evidence on his own behalf.

Qst.Quest: if he will make a special payment to the Society of St. Vincent de Paul in order that it can assist families on low incomes to purchase fuel, other than bituminous coal, when the ban on the purchase of such coal takes effect in Dublin on 1 September 1990.
if it is his intention to make a once-off payment to the Society of St. Vincent de Paul to assist it in helping people purchase smokeless fuel for the forthcoming winter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Dr. Woods) Michael J. Woods
Speaker.P: It is proposed to take Questions Nos. 166 and 169 together.

I am providing a special extra allowance of £3 per week for low income households to offset the additional costs arising from the ban on bituminous coal in built up areas of Dublin. Households in the restricted areas which already benefit under the national fuel scheme will qualify for the additional allowance.

In addition, the new allowance will apply to persons who are receiving short-term unemployment assistance, unemployment benefit or disability benefit for at least three months and persons receiving family income supplement who meet the other conditions for receiving a fuel allowance under the national fuel scheme. It is expected that approximately 81,000 households will benefit, at a cost of £6.32 million. The additional allowance will apply for the period of the heating season under the national fuel scheme, namely mid-October to mid-April.

These measures go well beyond the categories of persons covered by the national fuel scheme and represent a substantial package to counteract the extra cost of smokeless fuels. Any further measures would require additional funding.

Qst.Quest: if his attention has been drawn to the fact that dairy suppliers, shops and other outlets are refusing to accept the butter vouchers issued by his Department (details supplied); and the way in which these vouchers can be used by those receiving welfare payments who obtain them legitimately; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Dr. Woods) Michael J. Woods
Speaker.P: A difficulty in relation to the encashment of butter vouchers arose in the past few weeks when forged vouchers were discovered. This caused concern to a small number of outlets who refused to handle the vouchers.

Differences between forged and genuine vouchers were brought to the attention of retailers and suppliers and discussions have been held with them regarding their concerns. It is understood that the difficulties referred to have been resolved and that social welfare recipients in the locality mentioned can now use their vouchers in the ordinary way.
Arrangements have been made to have the security features of the vouchers improved and the new version will be available shortly.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Prescribed Relative's Allowance.

Qst.hpid: Mrs. T. Ahearn Mrs. T. Ahearn
Qst.Quest: if he will outline the number of persons in receipt of a prescribed relative's allowance for each of the years (a) 1987, (b) 1988, (c) 1989 and (d) 1990 in South Tipperary; the estimated number who will qualify for the new carer's allowance; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Dr. Woods) Michael J. Woods
Speaker.P: There is no breakdown by county of the number of prescribed relatives allowance recipients in 1987, 1988 or 1989. In April 1990 the total number of prescribed relative's allowances being paid by County Tipperary was 48. It is not possible to give a separate breakdown for north and south Tipperary, as records are not kept on this basis.

MainHeading.P: The total number of persons in receipt of prescribed relatives allowance in April 1990 was approximately 1,700. It is estimated that an additional 6,000 carers will qualify nation-wide for payments under the new carer's allowance scheme which is being introduced later this year.

Qst.Quest: when he proposes to remove the responsibility for court charges from local authorities; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mr. Burke) Raphael P. Burke
Speaker.P: The Government have decided in principle to transfer, from local authorities to the Exchequer, financial responsibility for courthouses. The details of how the decision will be applied are being discussed at present between my Department and the Department of Finance and in due course amending legislation will be required. I am not, therefore, in a position at this stage to go into details about how the new system will operate.

Qst.Quest: if, on the night of 30 March 1990, the only Garda patrol car operating in Blanchardstown, Dublin 15, had 123,000 miles on the clock; whether such a situation seriously impeded the efforts of the gardaí to preserve law and order in the area; the steps he has taken to ensure there will not be a recurrence; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mr. Burke) Raphael P. Burke
Speaker.P: A Garda patrol car with mileage of the order referred to in the question was on patrol in Blanchardstown on the night concerned. This vehicle was a temporary replacement car to Blanchardstown station pending repair of accidental damage to that station's regular patrol car. The Garda authorities inform me that the vehicle in question, despite its high mileage, was only two years old and in perfect mechanical order. It has since been withdrawn from the Garda fleet for auction.

Speaker.P: The Whitaker Committee recognised the difficulties of establishing a satisfactory rehabilitation programme for prisoners who use drugs and proposed a number of measures which, they considered, would improve the position. Speaker.NameTxt: Minister of State at the Department of the Environment (Miss Harney)

Qst.Quest: if, in relation to the operation of local authorities, he will give the size and estimated value of any project above which the local authority is required to seek competitive tenders; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Environment (Mr. Flynn) Minister for the Environment (Mr. Flynn)
Speaker.P: The decision as to the method by which a local authority project is to be undertaken is primarily a matter for the local authority concerned subject to the relevant legal and other general requirements.In particular, where a project is to be undertaken by contract the local authority must comply with the provisions of EC Directives on public works and supply contracts, which require that contracts of a value over the thresholds set out in the Directives must be advertised in the Official Journal of the European Communities. The threshold value (net of VAT) with effect from 1 January 1990 are as follows: Public Works Contracts — £777,550; and Public Supply Contracts — £155,510.

Procedures to be followed in the award of public contracts generally are set out in the document, “An Outline of Government Contracts Procedures” issued by the Department of Finance. These provide that, as a basic principle, a procedure based on a competitive tendering should be used save in exceptional circumstances.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Dublin Motorway Toll Plinths.

Qst.Quest: if he will outline who was responsible for the decision to construct toll plinths on the Western Parkway, Dublin; the consultations which took place prior to the decision; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Environment (Mr. Flynn) Minister for the Environment (Mr. Flynn)
Speaker.P: Following my Department's invitation of proposals for a toll franchise for the Dublin ring road in March 1989, a steering group representative of my Department, the Department of Finance and Dublin County Council was established to assess the proposals received. On foot of a recommendation from the steering group, it was decided to enter into detailed negotiations with a consortium led by Manufacturers Hanover Ltd. and including Cofiroute, with a view to concluding an agreement under the Local Government (Toll Roads) Act, 1979, in relation to the ring road, subject to the statutory procedures. In September, Dublin County Council was advised by letter of this decision. It was made clear to the local authority that any agreement reached with the consortium would be governed by the provisions of the 1979 Act.

MainHeading.P: Prior to the opening of the Naas Road-Galway Road section of the ring road, it was decided by the steering group that some preliminary works should be undertaken which would facilitate tolling in the event of such decision being made by the local authority. These works included the construction of toll plinths. The cost of the plinths would, of course, fall to be ment by the consortium in the event of a decision being reached by the local authority to enter into an agreement with them in relation to tolls. The decision to undertake these works in advance of opening of the road was made so as to avoid closure of sections of the route and consequent disruption of traffic, which would be necessary in the event of a decision by the local authority that tolls should be imposed subsequent to opening of the various sections of the ring road. The cost of the works at that stage would also be substantially greater.

I understand that the council has since directed the assistant manager concerned to arrange for the removal of the plinths which have been constructed at the Nass Road and Galway Road entry points. My Department will facilitate the local authority in this regard.

Speaker.P: The withdrawal of this scheme was an essential element of the recovery plan drawn up by the VHI to ensure their continued viability.

If VHI were requested to provide cover for routine medical costs, premiums would be too high to be affordable by most people. While the question of the reinstatement of the outpatient drugs scheme is primarily a matter for the VHI, it is difficult to envisage such an initiative being sustainable at the present time.

Assistance is, of course, available under the health boards drugs refund scheme which gives full recoupment for all expenditure in excess of £28 per month on prescribed drugs. I would also like to point out that the health boards may also give special consideration to persons who suffer undue hardship as a result of exceptional drug costs.

As stated in my reply of 6 June 1990 to Questions Nos. 18 and 29, Volume 399 of the Official Report, the introduction of a new community drug subsidisation scheme for persons with limited eligibility who have a regular and continuous need for expensive medication is currently the subject of ongoing discussions with the Irish Pharmaceutical Union.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Dr. O'Hanlon) Rory O'Hanlon
Speaker.P: An incident of salmonella at St. Finan's Hospital, Killarney, has been notified to my Department. A patient in a long stay ward was transferred to Tralee General Hospital on 2 March 1990 where the infection was identified. After treatment with antibiotics, the patient has recovered and returned to St. Finan's Hospital.

MainHeading.P: An investigation was carried out by the Southern Health Board and the organism was identified in four other patients who were also treated with antibiotics.
As a precautionery measure, tests are being carried out on all long stay patients and staff in the hospital. This has so far yielded negative results.
The director of community care for the area is satisfied that there is no risk of spread of the infection.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Dr. O'Hanlon) Rory O'Hanlon
Speaker.P: These moneys are held by each health board in bank accounts known as patients property accounts.
Health boards are trustees of patients' moneys. Patients' property accounts are independently audited.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Drug Pricing Agreement.

Qst.Quest: if he will make a statement on the talks which have taken place between his Department and the Federation of Irish Chemical Industry on a new drug pricing agreement; and if he will ensure that prices are brought in line with European price levels rather than with British levels, especially in view of the high inflation rate in Britain at present.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Dr. O'Hanlon) Rory O'Hanlon
Speaker.P: A new three year agreement with the Federation of Irish Chemical Industries was entered into last week. The agreement which replaces the current agreement, which expires on 31 July this year, will ensure that Irish prices will be protected from UK inflation where this is out of line with EC price movements. The main features of the new agreement are as follows:——

—The wholesale price of any product sold on the Irish market cannot be higher than the corresponding U.K. price. A standard 2 per cent discount will be payable on GMS medicines which will effectively bring the prices in the scheme below U.K. prices.
—Prices will be frozen for 12 months from 1 August.
—The prices of products which come on the market after 1 August will be based on a comparison with other European country prices for those products.

—In twelve months time the prices will be realigned. The realignment will limit increases to the average movement in a range of EC countries. This will ensure that where UK prices are significantly out of line the Irish price will be protected.
—Hospitals and health boards will continue to get a minimum 15 per cent discount but will be free to negotiate higher discounts where possible.

MainHeading.P: —My Department, under the terms of the agreement, reserves the right to influence the prescribing habits of doctors.

I am personally committed to the greater use of generic durgs and the medical profession will be encouraged to prescribe generic drugs where appropriate to ensure the full potential of savings to the Exchequer. My Department will very shortly be issuing a National Drugs Formulary for doctors which will be a major boost to cost-effective prescribing.
I am satisfied that the new agreement in conjunction with the measures outlined above, provides a sound basis for controlling drug prices on the Irish market.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Dr. O'Hanlon) Rory O'Hanlon

Until such time as a charter is formally adopted, I will be pursuing the question of appropriate provision for children in hospital. All hospitals, including childrens' hospitals, have recently been requested to consider taking initiatives on quality of patient care and to make proposals for action on this subject. These proposals will include a hospital code of conduct concerning visiting arrangements and amenities for patients and relatives.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Coach Safety Standards.

Qst.Quest: the regulations which exist regarding safety standards and working conditions on private coaches which transport passengers by ferry to Britain, or which transport passengers from provincial areas to Dublin; the supervision which is provided by his Department; and if he is satisfied that all coach operators are complying with the highest standards of passenger and driver safety.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Tourism and Transport (Mrs. S. Brennan) Seamus Brennan
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Tourism and Transport (Mrs. S. Brennan)
Speaker.P: The position in so far as my area of responsibility is concerned is as follows: Council Regulation (EEC) No. 3820/85 sets out, inter alia, the maximum permissible hours which coach drivers may operate and the minimum permissible durations of breaks and rest periods. Council Regulation (EEC) No. 3821/85 prescribes the installation and use of tachographs in vehicles. The regulations are implemented in this country by the European Communities (Road Transport) Regulations, 1986 (S. I. No. 392 of 1986) and European Communities (Road Transport) (Recording Equipment), Regulations 1986 (S. I. No. 393 of 1986).

MainHeading.P: The regulations apply to the carriage of passengers by road by passenger vehicles constructed and equipped to carry more than nine persons including the driver and where routes covered exceed 50 kilometres — 31 miles. The regulations require the use of either tachographs or duty rosters and service timetables, depending on the operation in which the vehicle is engaged.

The regulations are enforced both by the Garda Síochána and by the transport officers of my Department. Inspections are carried out by the transport officers in conjunction with the gardaí at roadside check points. While I am reasonably satisfied with the level of compliance with these regulations, the situation will be kept under constant review.
Other safety requirements, for example, relating to the roadworthiness of vehicles, are the responsibility of the Minister for the Environment.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Public Transport Investment Schemes.

Qst.Quest: in the context of the recently announced review of transport planning in the Dublin area, the public transport investment schemes which were grant aided by his Department in the administrative areas covered by Dublin Corporation, Dublin County Council and Dún Laoghaire Borough since the publication of the 1971 Dublin Transportation Study; if, in respect of each scheme he will indicate (a) the nature of the investment scheme, (b) its historic capital cost, net of VAT and (c) the interest charges which have been paid on any capital borrowed for the year in which the expenditure was incurred; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Tourism and Transport (Mr. S. Brennan) Seamus Brennan
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Tourism and Transport (Mr. S. Brennan)
Speaker.P: The main public transport investment schemes in the greater Dublin area undertaken since 1971 were as follows: (1) the electrification of the Bray-Howth rail service (DART) at a cost of £114 million, inclusive of £10 million VAT. This service came into operation in 1984; (ii) the provision of a commuter rail service from Maynooth to the city in 1980 at a cost of £0.25 million. This service will be upgraded with effect from July 1990 at a cost of £0.73 million; (iii) the installation of automatic vehicle monitoring systems in the Dublin Bus fleet in 1980 at a cost of £1.3 million; (iv) the upgrading of passenger facilities at Tara Street Station in 1990 at a cost of £1 million; and (v) bus priority and traffic management measures at a total cost of £4.2 million.

Expenditure on the projects at (ii) to (v) above was inclusive of VAT at 10 per cent. The projects at (i) to (iv) above were funded by CIE borrowings. The projects at (v) were funded by grants from the Tourism and Transport Vote. The cost of the interest charges on the DART, which amounted to £71.5 million by the end of 1989, have been borne directly by the Exchequer. The cost of the interest charges on the projects at (ii) to (iv) were borne by CIE.

Apart from the specific projects mentioned above, CIE's capital investment programme in the period also provided for an upgrading of the group's rail rolling stock, replacement and renewal of its bus fleet and the renewal of railway signalling.The rail and bus services provided by CIE in the greater Dublin area benefited significantly from these investments.

Qst.Quest: in view of the recent 24-hours stoppage of meteorological data at certain stations (details supplied), if he will make a statement on the validity of the forecasts given by the Irish Meteorological Service for the northern half of the country, with particular reference to fishing, boating and yachting interests, when no hourly data was available from any station north of a line from Shannon to Dublin.
if the stoppage of meteorological data, following industrial action at certain stations (details supplied), will have an impact on any aspect of public safety.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Tourism and Transport (Mr. S. Brennan) Seamus Brennan
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Tourism and Transport (Mr. S. Brennan)
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 265 and 266 together.

Whether forecasts issued by the Irish Meteorological Service are based on a vast range of data from a wide variety of sources including reports from Irish stations, from other countries and from ships in the Atlantic, on data from meteorological satellites and weather surveillance radar. In a volatile weather situation the absence of data from some normal sources could have adverse effects on the quality of forecasts. On 4 June relatively quiet conditions prevailed and there was no such impact and a comparison of actual weather conditions with the forecast issued revealed no detectable loss of quality. There was no impact on public safety.
Observations on 4 June were completed on site at the Irish synoptic stations and, while not transmitted for some stations, will be available for climatological and statistical purposes.
